results.title: Only the Brave
results.creator_credit: Pickpocket Productions, Fiona Eagger and Ana Kokkinos
results.brief_description: Alex (Elena Mandalis) and Vicki (Dora Kaskanis) are two young Greek Australian girls in Melbourne’s western suburbs. Only together - committing arson, hanging out - do they find moments of peace in their lives.

constellations_other.name: Ana Kokkinos
constellations_other.description: The films and TV works of Ana Kokkinos often explore the experiences of second-generation Australians, queer identities and class. Since beginning her career in the early 90s, those stories have started to appear more frequently on Australian screens.

results.creator_credit_for_label: Pickpocket Productions, Fiona Eagger and Ana Kokkinos
results.description: Alex (Elena Mandalis) and Vicki (Dora Kaskanis) are two young Greek Australian girls in Melbourne’s western suburbs. Vicki is bored with school and she is abused by her father at home. Alex misses her estranged mother and is trying to deal with her growing sexual attraction to a female teacher (well played by Maude Davey). Only together - committing arson, hanging out - do they find moments of peace in their lives. This tough short film is an outstanding example of a recent Australian cinema. Weaving themes of sexuality, ethnicity and dislocation, “Only the Brave” manages to be realist and elegiac, sensitive and uncompromising, and show how the impact of migration has altered the tradition, landscape and narratives of Australian culture. Mandalis and Kaskanis are knock-outs in their first screen performances and the the film received an AFI Award for best short film and the Audience Award at the Sundance Film Festival. Written by Ana Kokkinos and Mira Robertson.

results.title: Only ten pints
results.creator_credit: British Petroleum and St John Ambulance Australia
results.brief_description: The fear of blood can be easily dispelled and people can learn what to do in case of an amergency…in a First Aid Class. Clear diagrams and commentary show how lives may be saved when an accident causes any type of haemorrhage.

results.title: Only Benjy knows: should he tell?
results.creator_credit: Encyclopaedia Britannica Films and Gary Bergland
results.brief_description: Benjy sees some boys he knows shoplifting. They don’t see him and he doesn’t know whether to tell anyone. Is telling ever justified? This film aims to help students and teachers arrive at some flexible standards for dealing with this troublesome problem.

results.title: Only angels have wings
results.brief_description: Cary Grant heads a ramshackle cargo outfit in the wilds of South America, forced to fly in the most perilous of weather conditions to the most treacherous of destinations. Facing death on a near-hourly basis, Grant and his flyers have adopted a casual, all-in-a-day’s work attitude towards their mortality. Bringing more than a touch of glamour, and tension, to the sleepy one-saloon outpost is a showgirl (Jean Arthur) on her way to a nightclub engagement in Panama, and a fellow aviator’s beautiful wife (Rita Hayworth). Cast includes: Cary Grant, Jean Arthur, Rita Hayworth, Richard Barthelmess and Thomas Mitchell.

results.title: Oneiro: in the shadow of Isadora [NTSC]
results.creator_credit: Montclair State College and Silvianna Goldsmith
results.brief_description: Dance poem in three sections performed by Lori Belilove based on Belilove’s own choreography and improvisation as inspired by Isadora Duncan. Using special effects and computerized image processing, the dance sequences are superimposed onto images of ancient Greek temples, paintings, sculptures, and the Aegean Isles.

results.title: Onegin [Widescreen]
results.creator_credit: Baby Productions, Onegin Productions, Ileen Maisel, Simon Bosanquet and Martha Fiennes
results.brief_description: Jaded aristocrat, Evgeny Onegin (Ralph Fiennes), gladly abandons the decadent opulence of St. Petersburg’s high society after unexpectedly inheriting his uncle’s country estate. Despite feeling out of place in such a provincial setting, he manages to form an uneasy friendship with Vladimir Lensky (Toby Stevens), who introduces him to the sister of his fiance, Tatyana Larina (Liv Tyler). Tatyana becomes enamoured with Onegin and, caught up in the frenzy of first love, writes him a passionate letter expressing her feelings. However, she is devastated when Onegin cruelly rejects her and turns his attention to her sister, an action which eventually results in a duel with the enraged Lensky. Returning to St. Petersburg once again, Onegin spirals downward into a deep depression, obsessed with what might have been in this exquisitely filmed version of Alexander Pushkin’s famous novel, “Eugene Onegin”.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Baby Productions, Onegin Productions, Ileen Maisel, Simon Bosanquet and Martha Fiennes

results.title: One...two...sold!
results.brief_description: This film shows an example of one of the innovations being considered as an alternative to the traditional method of selling wool by auction at wool exhanges. The method proposed enables the woolbuyer to bid for any wool being offered for sale throughout Australia. Wool-buyers and woolbrokers are linked by an extensive network of computer outlets, which enables wool sales to be conducted without the face to face contact at a wool exchange.

results.title: One, two, three
results.creator_credit: Mirsch, United Artists Corporation, Pyramid Films and Billy Wilder
results.brief_description: James Cagney shines in a virtuoso, verbal machine-gun fire perfomance as an American executive trying to sell Coca Cola to the Russians while preventing his boss’s daughter from marrying an East-German communist. How the would-be groom is converted into a capitalist before her parents arrive is part of this first-class farce.

results.title: One, two, three
results.creator_credit: Unesco, Hungarofilm, Gyula Macskassy and Gyorgy Varnai
results.brief_description: Traces the history of our numerals and system of mathematics. Numerals originated in India, spread to Arabia where Algebra was first conceived and then to Greece. Pythagoras and Archimedes added their contributions, and in the middle ages mathematics was introduced to the Universities of Spain. Merchants rapidly disseminated the new international language throughout Europe. Scientific development, the basis of our modern age owes everything to the principles of mathematics. Animation by Grete Maday, Janos Mata and Marcell Jankovics.

results.title: One year performance
results.brief_description:
Tehching Hsieh. Hsieh’s work consists of five ‘One Year Performances’ executed between the years of 1978 and 1886 and ‘Earth’ a thirteen year performance that stretched from the end of 1986 to the end of 1999. Each of these Performances involved a particular vow, a particular constraint, a particular mode of being. Each of them is meticulously documented in a manner appropriate to its content. Each of Hsieh’s performances was a singular event: an action, or a series of actions, that occurred in a designated place during a finite period of time. Although Hsieh never explicitly states the rationale for his one-year pieces they nonetheless resound with profound questions about life, art and being. In one sense, the Hsieh’s life work is an endeavour to make art and life collide.The performances themselves are as weird as they are wonderful intersecting with a diverse range of themes such as isolation, solitude, displacement, human relationships and artistic documentation. The first of the One Year Performances had the artist lock himself inside a cage for an entire year. The second One Year Performance, saw the artist punch a time clock, every hour on the hour, twenty-four hours a day for a whole year. The third One Year Performance, in contrast to the first two, had the artist living out of doors for an entire twelve month period, while the fourth One Year Performance, a collaboration with Linda Montano, had both artists tied together by an eight-foot rope over the year period. The fifth and final One Year Performance, where the artists imposed a blanket moratorium on anything artistic, became in and of itself a
conceptual investigation and negation of the previous four On Year Performances. Apart from being serious (yet undeniably droll) meditations on significant existential questions, Hsieh’s documentations are also clever, practical reports on the formal capabilities of the mysterious time-and-memory-machine that is the recorded moving image.
